------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

And in addition to the student answer, EECS did not have 162 and 170 as graduation requirements because there might be students who want to focus completely on an EE track. That being said, I do think people focusing on the CS-end should probably consider 170 and 162 to be de-facto graduation requirements, although... I am biased.
For what it's worth, I heard that 162 and 170 both used to be requirements for CS (but not EECS) not too long ago, but they removed the requirement to make it more in line with EECS.

There are a diversity of good paths through the department. And one can create multiple completely reasonable 4-year-plans that skip any one upper-division course.  And yes, that includes 170 too now. The lower-division by contrast, is all essential for everyone. (There was a bug for a bit when LSCS wasn't required to take both 16AB but that has since been fixed.)

Furthermore, it was assumed that students should be talking to their faculty adviser about their course paths holistically, and that students would be picking faculty advisers who understand broadly the areas that they want to engage with. (This was about a factor of three fewer students ago, when faculty advising could also be mandated in the system.) The concept was that if students instead used the flexibility to pick wrong-headed course lists, they would know they are doing something silly but that it was their choice. And on balance, it was better to permit flexibility than to demand petitions. 

Of course, the flexibility also technically permits lots of course plans that are quite bad. The idea was that faculty advising would take one look and say "that is really not a good idea" and students would change. Just because there are lots of good paths doesn't mean that all paths are good! And not all paths are good for every student. A good program helps students constantly grow in a way that matches their strengths while patching their weaknesses. A faculty adviser is supposed to see student's grades and resume' and be able to advise accordingly. Nobody ever thought that a student on their own or a peer would be able to do this selection on their own given just the course catalog.

The idea was also that the lower-division would give students a broad exposure (since students are supposed to complete the lower division before taking any upper division courses in the department). And students could always go to faculty office hours in the lower division to ask for generic course advice too. 

With the reasonably light requirements (except for transfers for whom the requirements are quite intense), there was also some room for error and experimentation. 

That was the idea anyway.

This question is out of pure curiosity, and not a "make 170 a graduation requirement" kind of post. From every professor I've talked to and post I've read on this Piazza (and from the contents of the course), it's very clear 170 is such a fundamental part of a Berkeley CS education, and CS as a whole. If this is the case, then why is 170 not listed as an upper division major requirement for CS majors, in the same way real/complex analysis is a requirement for Math majors? Is it to promote diversity in a student's UD course choices? Just wondering. Thanks!
